ol.li: The most general form of a second-degree equation in two variables is Ax^2 + Bxy + Cy^2 + Dx + Ey + F = 0 where A, B, and C cannot all be zero, and its graph is a conic section.
An ellipse is the set of points in the plane the sum of whose distances from two fixed points (called the foci) is a constant.
The standard form for an ellipse centered at the origin is \dfrac{x^2}{a^2} + \dfrac{y^2}{b^2} = 1
A hyperbola is the set of points in the plane, the difference of whose distances from two fixed points (the foci) is a constant.

The standard form for a hyperbola centered at the origin with foci on the x-axis is \dfrac{x^2}{a^2} - \dfrac{y^2}{b^2} = 1 The standard form for a hyperbola centered at the origin with foci on the y-axis is \dfrac{y^2}{b^2} - \dfrac{x^2}{a^2} = 1
We can draw the asymptotes by first forming the "central rectangle," whose sides pass through the vertices and covertices. The asymptotes are the diagonals of this rectangle.
A parabola is the set of points in the plane whose distances from a fixed line l and a fixed point F are equal.

Parabolas with vertex at the origin have equations of the form y=\dfrac{x^2}{4p} ~~~~~~ \text{or} ~~~~~~ y=\dfrac{-x^2}{4p} ~~~~~~ \text{or} ~~~~~~ x=\dfrac{y^2}{4p} ~~~~~~ \text{and} ~~~~~~ x=\dfrac{-y^2}{4p}
